results.title: Victorian Tapestry Workshop
results.creator_credit: Ivan Hexter, Victorian Film Corporation and Paul Jansen
results.brief_description: The Victorian Tapestry Workshop was established in 1976 with State Government assistance. This film shows the efforts of the workshop in transforming a Roger Kemp painting into a major tapestry.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ivan Hexter, Victorian Film Corporation and Paul Jansen

results.title: Lockdown finally coming to an end
results.brief_description: After winning the unenvious title of most lock-down city in the world, Melbournians could certainly relate to Willy the Whale’s fantastic feeling of freedom in the pivotal scene of early 90’s classic, Free Willy. Originally posted in 2020 at the end of Victoria’s mammoth 112-day lockdown number two, the clip, feels all the more relevant in 2021 after a total of 263 days spent across six periods of lockdown captivity.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

After living in one of the world’s most locked-down cities, Melburnians could certainly relate to Willy the whale’s feeling of freedom in the climax of early 90s classic, Free Willy. Originally posted in 2020 at the end of Victoria’s mammoth 112-day second lockdown, the clip feels all the more relevant in 2021 after a total of 262 days spent across six periods of stay-at-home orders.
description_for_label: After living in one of the world’s most locked-down cities, Melburnians could certainly relate to Willy the whale’s feeling of freedom in the climax of early 90s classic, Free Willy. Originally posted in 2020 at the end of Victoria’s mammoth 112-day second lockdown, the clip feels all the more relevant in 2021 after a total of 262 days spent across six periods of stay-at-home orders.

results.title: Victorian cast iron
results.creator_credit: Edward Hayward, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: A look at some of the remains of Victorian cast iron in Great Britain, and some earlier examples with some discussion as to why they are important and representative of the period. Cast iron has survived better than any of the other new materials discussed, although much was lost for scrap during the wars, and many important monuments are being pulled down yearly.

results.title: Victoria University Student Collection 2001
results.brief_description:
CD ROM work provided by Victoria University of exemplary work produced by students in their multimedia courses.

This interactive CD Rom and website documentary explores the life and music of virtuoso guitarist Slava Grigoryan.

The website and CD ROM hybrid allows for regular updates and particularly suited to the work as the guitarist travels frequently and can list concert and publication updates.

results.title: Victoria Howlett: potter
results.creator_credit: Nina Syme, Terry McMahon and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”.
Victoria Howlett regards her pottery as a reflection of her personality, her travels and her various experiences. She finds inspiration for her work in nature and approaches her tasks very systematically.

results.title: Victoria changing faces changing places
results.brief_description: This short documentary addresses the issues that surround Victoria’s growing population, whilst also probing the past and how migration helped shaped the current demographic. Using voice-over narration, this features an array of archival footage to examine the underlying drivers of population growth, with a view to understanding how the community is changing, and the what the future is likely to hold for Victoria.

results.title: Victoria's Favourite Things. Segment 9
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘Victoria’s Favourite Things’. This segment features Maya and her fairy costume; Jennifer from Regent talks about Bernadette and Lucinda; Kieran from St Kilda loves football; Kay has a favourite hat and scarf; and Monica from Avondale Heights talks about Meditation.
